qas.question: Buridan's theory of impetus led to what modern concept?

qas.question: Which scholars made no advances in the theories of motion?

context: This new approach liberated scientific speculation from the dogmatic restraints of <a1_0><b7_0>Aristotelian<b7_0/><a1_0/> science, and paved the way for new approaches. Particularly within the field of theories of motion great advances were made, when such scholars as <a3_0><b9_0>Jean Buridan, Nicole Oresme and the Oxford Calculators<b9_0/><a3_0/> challenged the work of Aristotle. Buridan developed <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>the theory of impetus<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> as the cause of the motion of projectiles, which was an important step towards the modern concept of <a4_0>inertia<a4_0/>. The works of these scholars anticipated the heliocentric worldview of <a2_0><b8_0>Nicolaus Copernicus<b8_0/><a2_0/>.
